Fig. 4 Catalytic activities for CO oxidation over the Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) Catalytic performance of various Co3O4 catalysts at room temperature. Reaction conditions: 200mg catalyst, 1% CO–20% O2 balanced with He, 50mLmin−1. (b) Time-on-stream change of CO conversion over GO-300 catalyst (20mg) in a feed stream containing 1% CO and 20% O2 at room temperature. Fig. 6 The CO-titration profiles of all the samples at room temperature. Fig. 7 O 1s XPS spectra of all the samples after pretreated in the O2/He. Fig. 8 The O2-TPD profiles of the Co3O4 catalysts. Structure and catalytic performances of nanocrystalline Co3O4 catalysts for low temperature CO oxidation prepared by dry and wet synthetic routes Changxiang Liu Qian Liu ⁎ Ling Bai Aiqin Dong Guangbin Liu Shihe Wen College of Science, Jiangxi Agricultural University, Nanchang 330045, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 791 83828064; fax: +86 791 83828064. Graphical abstract Nanocrystalline Co3O4 prepared by wet-chemical precipitation and dry solid-state grinding route, respectively. The grinding-derived catalyst calcined at 300°C was satisfying with the 50% conversion of CO at −92°C, showing superior catalytic ability than that of the precipitation-derived sample (T 50 =35°C). It was proved that pretreatment in O2 atmosphere of grinding-derived catalysts enhanced the formation of surface reactive oxygen species to react with CO. Highlights ► Co3O4 prepared by different routes show distinct performances for CO oxidation. ► The grinding-derived catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity (T 50% =−92°C). ► The process of mechanochemical activation promotes the formation of structural defect. ► The amount of weakly adsorbed O− species plays a key role in CO oxidation on Co3O4. The nanocrystalline Co3O4 catalysts were prepared via wet-chemical precipitation and dry-solid-state reaction, respectively. To assess the suitability of such Co3O4 as an oxidation catalyst, CO oxidation was taken as model reaction. The best catalyst was obtained by dry grinding route calcined at 300°C, showing the 50% conversion of CO at −92°C, under a stream of normal feed gas containing moisture. Comparing the reaction rate per cobalt oxide mass unit at room temperature (ca. 1.53mmolg−1 s−1) with the Au-based catalyst in the current literature confirmed the exceptionally high activity of these new materials. The as-synthesized catalysts have been characterized by various techniques in a view of material characterization, as well as to investigate the mechanistic aspects of catalytic reactions. Examination of the surface nature of the materials by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) shows that O− and lattice oxygen (O2−) are the predominant species at the oxidized surface. In addition, a close parallel between the catalytic activity and the concentration of O− oxygen species indicates that a large amount of more mobile and reactive O− species is the main reason for its enhanced CO oxidation activity. Keywords Co3O4 Solid state synthesis CO oxidation Active oxygen species 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation of CO at low temperature is becoming increasingly important recently due to its significance in pollution control for vehicle exhaust, human safety in mines, deep sea diving, indoor air cleaning, as well as to meet stringent environmental regulations [1,2]. Precious metal catalysts, especially gold based catalysts have been studied for CO oxidation and showed high activities [3–6]. However, due to high prices and scarce of noble metal, attention has been given to transition metal oxides. Among them, Co3O4 (bulk or supported) catalysts have been extensively studied [7–11]. Depending on the preparation method for the materials and the reaction conditions, Co3O4 shows different activity in CO oxidation. Recently Xie et al. [12] reported that tricobalt tetraoxide nanorods catalyzed CO oxidation at temperatures as low as −77°C, using ethylene glycol as organic solvent. Feng et al. [13] prepared Co3O4 polycrystals using a thermal decomposition method. Its full CO conversion can be reached at as low as −70°C. Tüysüz et al. [14] synthesized ordered mesoporous Co3O4 via a nanocasting pathway and found it was active but not stable. Wang et al. [15] found that the Co3O4 prepared by precipitation-oxidation method with hydrogen peroxide exhibited higher activity than that prepared by impregnation or hydrothermal due to the use of oxidant. Yu Yao [16] studied kinetic parameters and Jansson [17] studied the deactivation mechanism, but the activity or stability was not good. Haruta's group reported light-off temperature (temperature of 50% conversion, T 50) as low as −54°C under conditions only if the reaction gas was meticulously dried (moisture <1ppm). At normal operation (moisture 3–10ppm), the T 50 was around 40°C [18]. From the results of the literatures it can be seen that the conventional wet-chemistry routes are quite popular. However, these processes often have many disadvantages such as tedious multistep processing, the formation of environmental wastes and the cost of surfactant and oxidant. Over the past decades, grinding-assisted solid state synthesis has attracted tremendous attention by providing a much simpler, waste-free, easily scalable and energy-efficient technique for fabrication of new catalytic materials with improved and/or novel physical and chemical properties [19]. Solsona et al. found that the Co3O4 prepared by mechanochemical grinding exhibited high activity for C3H8 oxidation [20]. Wang et al. reported the synthesis of CuO nanowhiskers by the solid-state reaction in the presence of PEG-400 [21]. Kaliaguine and co-workers demonstrated that perovskite-type materials could be synthesized by the reactive grinding [22]. Wang et al. prepared Cu/ZnO catalysts highly efficient for methanol steam re-forming based on mechanochemical activation [23]. Cao et al. studied the gas-sensing properties of the ZnO nanoparticles and nanorods obtained from room-temperature solid-state chemical reaction [24]. However, there have been few studies concerning the catalytic performances for CO oxidation of cobalt oxide synthesized by dry solid-phase reaction. In the present work, two types of Co3O4 catalysts were synthesized by wet-chemical and dry-grinding route, respectively. Their activities for CO oxidation were evaluated and compared for the first time. The studies have mainly focused on (1) exploring the influence of synthetic route on the textural, structural, morphological, redox properties, and CO oxidation activities of Co3O4 catalysts; (2) trying to understand the surface structures of the catalysts and establish the structure–property relationship. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2CoCO3·3Co(OH)2·H2O premixed with 20% stoichiometric excess of H2C2O4·2H2O was loaded into a plastic vial with agate milling balls. The weight ratio between the balls and powders was 10:1. The grinding was carried out in a planetary mill (QM-1SP04) at a speed of 600rpm for 2h. After the completion of grinding, the as-ground product was separated and calcined at 300, 400, 500 and 600°C in air for 4h. The final calcined samples were designated as GO-t, where t stands for the calcination temperature. For comparison, the Co3O4 catalyst was also obtained by the wet-chemical method. In short, a 1.2M aqueous solution of Na2CO3 was added into an aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate (0.5M) under vigorous stirring. The temperature was kept at 80°C during precipitation and maintaining the pH at 8.5. The precipitate was washed thoroughly and dried in air at 110°C for 12h, followed by calcination at 400°C in air for 4h. The final calcined sample was designated as CP-400. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The BET specific surface areas were determined by adsorption–desorption of nitrogen at liquid nitrogen temperature, using a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 equipment. XRD analyses were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Avance X-Ray Diffractometer with nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation. H2-TPR profiles were obtained on a homemade apparatus. The total flow rate of the feed (5vol% H2/Ar) was 40mLmin−1. Before experiment the sample (20mg) was preheated in a stream of air at 200°C for 30min, and then cooled to room temperature. The sample was heated at a ramping rate of 5°Cmin−1 to a final temperature of 600°C. The H2 consumption was monitored using a TCD detector. In CO-titration technique, the catalyst was pretreated in 20vol% O2/He at 200°C for 0.5h. After cooling to room temperature, the system was purged in He (60mLmin−1) for 3h. Then the 5vol% CO/He stream was injected until no CO2 was observed in the effluent gases. The evolution of CO2 concentration was monitored by online mass spectrometer (Balzers OmniStar). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were recorded with a Perkin Elmer PHI 5000C system equipped with a hemispherical electron energy analyzer. The carbonaceous C 1s line (284.6eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energies (BE). O2-TPD was also carried out in the fixed-bed flow reactor. The catalyst (200mg) was pretreated in helium at 300°C for 2h, then the oxygen adsorption was proceeded with 20vol% O2/He at 200°C for 0.5h. After cooling to room temperature, the system was purged in He for 1h. Then the temperature was raised to 800°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in the helium flow, and the effluent gases were analyzed with a Balzers Omnistar benchtop mass spectrometer. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic tests for CO oxidation were performed at atmospheric pressure in a quartz tube micro reactor. The catalyst weight was 200mg, and the reaction gas containing 1vol% CO, 20vol% O2 and 79vol% He was fed directly without any dry purification. The total flow rate was 50mLmin−1. Prior to CO oxidation reaction, the catalysts were pretreated with 20vol% O2/He at 200°C for 0.5h. The composition of the influent and effluent gas was detected with an online GC-17A gas chromatograph equipped with a TDX-01 column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural features of the calcined catalysts Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of all the catalysts, illustrating that Co3O4 is the only phase. The average crystallite sizes are listed in Table 1 . The order of particle size is: GO-300 (11nm)<GO-400 (18nm)<CP-400 (21nm)<GO-500 (33nm)<GO-600 (45nm). On the other hand, the grinding-derived catalyst can afford the favorable creation of highly strained nanocrystals. As shown in Table 1, the microstrain value in the grinding-derived Co3O4 nanocrystals was observed to be much higher than the CP catalyst. This indicates the presence of a high lattice distortion in the cobalt spinel structure of the grinding-derived samples. A similar microstructural modification due to an increased portion of point defects has already been reported by Lopes et al. for Co3O4 nanoparticles of different sizes confined in mesoporous SBA-15 materials [25]. Thus, it can be concluded that highly strained Co3O4 nanocrystals with enhanced structural disorder could be readily obtained through the dry-grinding route. The specific areas (S BET) of all the catalysts are given in Table 1. It is apparent that the BET surface area of GO-300 is twice that of the catalysts obtained by precipitation. Comparison of the grinding-derived samples reveals that increasing the calcination temperature results in a sintering process which reduces the specific surface area. The TEM images of the Co3O4 samples are presented in Fig. 2 . Particles with rounded contours formed as the result of heating at 300°C, while those heated at higher temperature exhibited polyhedral shape. The particles are apt to aggregate together with increasing the calcination temperature, from 11nm for GO-300 to 45nm for GO-600. The particle sizes estimated from TEM are generally consistent with the XRD results. Note that the dry-grinding derived GO-400 has smaller size than the precipitation-derived CP-400 catalyst. This further clarifies that the solid-phase approach can allow the preparation of much smaller Co3O4 nanoparticles compared to the conventional wet chemical methods. To further investigate the reducibility of the Co3O4 catalysts, TPR measurements were carried out and shown in Fig. 3 . All the samples exhibit similar TPR profiles, consisting of two well-resolved reduction peaks (assigned as α and β peaks). According to the literature [26], it shows the subsequent structure change to CoO, which followed the higher temperature and reduction of CoO to metallic cobalt. As can be seen in Fig. 3, both the α and β peaks slightly shift to higher temperatures as the particle size increases for grinding-derived catalysts. The CP-400 sample has stronger reducibility than that of GO-400. It can be seen that the reducibility of the cobalt species was strongly dependent on the preparation method. 3.2 Catalytic activities The catalytic activities of CO oxidation over the catalysts are compared in Fig. 4 . The T 50 over all catalysts are given in Table 1. Interestingly, the GO-300 sample is found to be extremely active, successfully converting 50% of CO at temperature around −92°C under a stream of normal feed gas containing moisture, corresponding to a space velocity of 15,000mLgcat −1 h−1. As a comparison, the T 50 over CP-400 is 35°C. For all the samples, the activity decreased in the following sequence: GO-300>GO-400>GO-500>GO-600>CP-400. Note that the grinding-derived sample calcined at 600°C even have higher activity than the 400°C-calcined ones synthesized by precipitation. As shown in Fig. 5a, the solid-state reaction derived cobalt oxides also demonstrate higher stability as a function of reaction time at room temperature than precipitation-derived sample. The GO-300 sample showed 100% CO conversion to CO2 for 10h. However, the precipitation-derived catalyst is substantially deactivated. Hence, these newly synthesized nanostructured Co3O4 spinel oxides are proven to be superior in catalytic activity and stability for the low temperature CO oxidation. To obtain reliable results of the stability, the mass of GO-300 catalyst was adjusted to ensure that conversion was lower than 100% at room temperature. As seen from Fig. 5b, a relatively strong initial deactivation was observed over the first 2h after the catalyst was put on stream. The deactivation rate slowed down significantly in the period after 2h on stream, but only down to 82% after 10h. The measured reaction rate per cobalt oxide mass unit at room temperature was 1.53mmolg−1 s−1. It is also interesting to make a further comparison of the activity of GO-300 with other noble metal catalysts. For example, our previous work showed that the mass-specific reaction rate of Au/Mn2O3 catalyst for CO oxidation under similar reaction conditions was 1.50mmolgAu −1 s−1 [4]. The rough comparison reveals that the solid-state reaction derived Co3O4 catalyst appears to be a promising candidate in replacement of precious metal catalysts for CO oxidation. 3.3 Active oxygen analysis Previous studies on cobalt oxide-based catalysts showed that a number of parameters such as the crystallite size, the surface area, as well as the strength of CoO bond are thought to be of relevance to understand the observed catalytic behavior for the oxidation of CO [26–28]. Note that, compared to GO-500 and GO-600 catalyst, the CP-400 sample in the present work has smaller crystallite size, larger surface area, better reducibility but the worst catalytic performance. No direct structure–activity relation was found from the XRD, BET, TEM, and H2-TPR characterizations. As a consequence, other factors may play a vital role in determining the observed high activities of grinding-derived Co3O4 catalysts. In order to obtain more information regarding the capability of Co3O4 catalysts to activate oxygen, a CO-titration technique was employed. Fig. 6 shows the transient response of CO2 evolution over a series of Co3O4 catalysts by switching from pure He to 5vol% CO in He at room temperature. For GO-300, a sharp and narrow CO2 peak emerged in the absence of gas phase oxygen. According to Wang et al. [8], the peak could be ascribed to the reaction of CO with the highly reactive oxygen species formed during the pretreatment process on the catalysts. It is important to note that the peak intensity follows the order: GO-300>GO-400>GO-500>GO-600>CP-400. The result clearly demonstrates that the grinding-derived catalyst, especially with lower calcination temperature has a superior capability to activate the molecular oxygen in the reactant gas, leading to the generation of highly reactive surface oxygen species thus significantly enhanced activity in the oxidation of CO. The O 1s XPS spectra were obtained for all the Co3O4 samples to gain further information on the chemical states of the cobalt species and the oxygen species on the catalyst surfaces (Fig. 7 ). A broad peak is identified for all samples indicating the existence of several kinds of surface oxygen species. Deconvolution of the original O 1s features was carried out and the peak positions and their contributions extracted from the deconvolution are summarized in Table 2 . The species with binding energies at about 529.3 and 531.1eV as measured for all samples are attributed to lattice O2− and surface O− species, respectively [29,30]. A comparison of the surface concentrations of oxygen species leads to the conclusion that the amount of the O− species has largely depended on the synthesis route and calcination temperature. Therefore, in combination of the CO-titration characterization, the O− species is the possible active oxygen species leading to high activities and stabilities for CO oxidation. To further investigate the nature of the active oxygen species, TPD chromatograms of oxygen were carried out. As shown in Fig. 8 , all the catalysts display three prominent characteristic peaks. The first peak (α1) implies that the desorbed oxygen species may be physically/chemically adsorbed oxygen [29,31]. The second peak (α2) is more reasonable attributed to the desorption of O− species [29,31]. The third peak (β) perhaps comes from the lattice oxygen on the surface of Co3O4 catalyst. More attention should be paid to the first two desorption peaks, since they can be desorbed under relatively low temperatures are likely to participate in the oxidation reactions. As can be seen from Fig. 8 that the amount of α1 oxygen species has no regular change rule. It was also proved by calculated relative peak area based on the reference catalyst CP-400 (Table 1). A phenomenon worthy of note is that for GO-t catalysts, with increasing the calcination temperature, a significant decrease of the α2 peak is identified. Moreover, the amount of O− species released from CP-400 is the lowest. This is in accordance with the XPS results discussed above, most likely due to the reduced density of lattice defects. Thus, a close parallel between the catalytic activity and the concentration of O− oxygen species indicates that a large amount of reactive O− oxygen species is the main reason for enhanced CO oxidation activity. As a matter of fact, a number of workers have proposed electrophilic oxygen species to be the key oxidant in the oxidation of CO oxidation [8,32]. However, the results seem in contrast with the general idea that lattice oxygen usually oxidizes CO. It seems reasonable to argue that if there are more active sites, the adsorbed O− species will be considered to be the main species responsible for enhancing the activity of Co3O4 catalyst at so low temperature. It is clear that the present mechanochemical processing can allow the effective creation of high density of surface defects, which might play an important role in accelerating the activation and dissociation of oxygen molecules leading to the formation of chemisorbed O− species. 4 Conclusions In this work, the effects of preparation method and calcination temperature on the physicochemical properties of Co3O4 catalysts were investigated. The results show that the dry grinding synthesized catalysts are more active than the corresponding precipitation-derived Co3O4 for CO oxidation model reaction. Especially the GO-300 catalyst exhibited promising performance for CO oxidation, giving 50% conversion at −92°C and good stability. The results of XPS and O2-TPD show that O− and lattice oxygen (O2−) are the predominant species on the oxidized Co3O4 surface. However, the grinding-derived catalysts are easy to form a high abundant of readily accessible superficial O− species, which is the main reason for enhanced CO oxidation activity. This finding provides a novel guideline for the creation of transition metal oxide catalysts with high activity at low temperatures. coredata.dc:description: The nanocrystalline Co3O4 catalysts were prepared via wet-chemical precipitation and dry-solid-state reaction, respectively. To assess the suitability of such Co3O4 as an oxidation catalyst, CO oxidation was taken as model reaction. The best catalyst was obtained by dry grinding route calcined at 300°C, showing the 50% conversion of CO at −92°C, under a stream of normal feed gas containing moisture. Comparing the reaction rate per cobalt oxide mass unit at room temperature (ca. 1.53mmolg−1 s−1) with the Au-based catalyst in the current literature confirmed the exceptionally high activity of these new materials. The as-synthesized catalysts have been characterized by various techniques in a view of material characterization, as well as to investigate the mechanistic aspects of catalytic reactions. Examination of the surface nature of the materials by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) shows that O− and lattice oxygen (O2−) are the predominant species at the oxidized surface. In addition, a close parallel between the catalytic activity and the concentration of O− oxygen species indicates that a large amount of more mobile and reactive O− species is the main reason for its enhanced CO oxidation activity.
coredata.dc:title: Structure and catalytic performances of nanocrystalline Co3O4 catalysts for low temperature CO oxidation prepared by dry and wet synthetic routes
